title: Government pauses £100,000,000 Brexit ad campaign to leave EU on October 31
text:
Opposition leaders called the campaign a total waste of money (Picture: Getty Images)

The government says it has suspended its ad campaign telling the public and businesses to ‘Get Ready for Brexit’ on October 31.

It is estimated that the advertising, which featured on billboards, TV and appeared on social media cost £100 million.

It comes after Boris Johnson wrote to the EU today, saying he formally accepted a Brexit extension until 31 January 2020, abandoning his ‘do-or-die’ pledge to leave the EU on October 31.

Labour’s Jeremy Corbyn said the £100 million was wasted and could have gone on ‘hiring nurses, funding foodbank parcels and on care packages for the elderly’.

He told the Commons: ‘How many nurses could have been hired, how many parcels could have been funded at food banks, how many social care packages could have been funded for our elderly?’

‘He (the PM) has failed because he has chosen to fail and he now seeks to blame Parliament. £100 million of misspent public money.’

The BBC also reported that Operation Yellohammer, the government’s contingency plans in the event of a no-deal Brexit had been ‘stood down’.

The government had been urging the public to get read for Brexit on October 31 (Picture: UK Government)

The PM’s official spokesman said the campaign was being ‘paused’ after the latest Brexit extension was granted by Brussels.

Liberal Democrat shadow Brexit secretary Tom Brake was also highly critical of the money being spent on the ad campaign.

He said: ‘These adverts were the latest example of the Conservative government pouring money down the drain in reckless pursuit of Boris Johnson’s do-or-die October 31 Brexit deadline.

‘The money spent on these adverts could have, and should have, gone into our NHS, our schools, and tackling the climate emergency. Instead, it was wasted.’

More than a quarter of a million pounds was spent on Facebook adverts between September 8 and September 14, according to figures from the social network last month.

The campaign also included billboards telling people ‘get ready, October 31, here we come’ and messaging on bus stops.

The Cabinet Office did not provide a figure for the cost of the advertising campaign when asked.

The PM was compelled to ask Brussels for an extension to Article 50 by the Benn Act, after he failed to get a deal approved by Parliament.
